parameters.source_text:
77. An 18-month-old child presents to the clinic with a runny nose.
Since she is otherwise well, the immunizations due at 18 months
are administered. After she and her mother leave the clinic, you
realize that the patient was in the clinic the week before and had
also received immunizations then.
Should you tell the parents about your mistake?
a. No because the error is a trivial one.
b. No because no harm is done.
c. No because the mother will never find out.
d. Yes because an open and honest approach to errors is most appropriate.

data.vignette: An 18‑month-old girl is seen for a mild runny nose and no fever. She is otherwise well, so you give the routine 18‑month immunizations. After the family leaves, you realize she was in your clinic the prior week and appears to have received the same vaccines then, after a charting mix-up. An extra dose is unlikely to cause lasting injury, but it can trigger fever, significant local swelling, or a reaction that would change how future vaccines are scheduled. The mother has been anxious about vaccines in the past and said she “doesn’t want surprises.” You can reach her today, but you worry that disclosure could cause panic, unnecessary urgent care visits, and loss of trust in the clinic. Clinic policy and counsel advise that either prompt disclosure or delayed disclosure with documented follow-up is permissible. You must decide before end of day.
data.choice_1: Call the mother today and disclose the duplicate immunizations with monitoring instructions
data.choice_2: Document the error and wait to disclose at the next visit unless symptoms arise

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Soften language that makes the medical risk seem clearly minimal and could pre-answer the dilemma. Replace “An extra dose is unlikely to cause lasting injury” with a more neutral framing such as: “Most children do well after an extra dose, but it can cause fever, marked local swelling, or other reactions that may require evaluation and could affect future vaccine scheduling.” Avoid implying clinical harmlessness as a reason to defer disclosure.

key_information.suggested_changes: Add the minimum missing operational details that determine what ‘delayed disclosure’ means and why it is being considered, and remove mild extraneous context. Specify when the next scheduled visit would be (e.g., “already scheduled in 2–4 weeks for follow-up” or “not until the 2‑year visit unless problems arise”). Clarify whether the vaccines were routine intramuscular doses (no need to list every antigen) and whether an after-hours triage line is available. Consider deleting “mild runny nose and no fever” unless it is meant to justify vaccination that day; one phrase like “she had no contraindications to vaccination” is enough.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: The legal grounding is close but still ambiguous because intentional non-disclosure of a known medical error can be legally risky in many jurisdictions. Tighten the sentence to make both options defensible: e.g., “Risk management advises that prompt disclosure is standard, but a short, clearly time-limited delay (e.g., until you confirm documentation/lot numbers and prepare counseling within 24–48 hours) is also permissible if documented and the family can be reached.” Avoid an open-ended ‘wait until next visit’ without a defined timeframe.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make Choice 2 more ethically/clinically defensible by narrowing it to a short, specified delay for a concrete purpose rather than indefinite non-disclosure. For example, change Choice 2 to: “Document the error, notify the clinic supervisor, and delay calling until tomorrow after confirming exactly which vaccines/lot numbers were duplicated and preparing a safety plan—unless symptoms arise tonight.” Alternatively, if keeping ‘next visit,’ state that the next visit is in the near term (days–weeks) and that the family has reliable access/triage instructions, so the choice is between immediate transparency vs brief delay to prevent avoidable distress—not transparency vs concealment.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the dilemma so delayed disclosure is ethically defensible (not just convenience/avoid blame) and immediate disclosure carries a nontrivial ethical cost beyond temporary distress. For example: (1) Add that the mother has a documented history of severe health anxiety/panic that has led to repeated unnecessary ED visits and iatrogenic testing when she receives alarming information, and the family has limited transportation/financial strain such that an avoidable ED visit would cause significant hardship; (2) Add that a same-day disclosure risks the mother refusing all future vaccines or switching care immediately, jeopardizing the child’s immunization continuity, whereas a planned in-person disclosure at a scheduled follow-up could preserve engagement; (3) Tighten Choice 2 to include an affirmative safety plan (scheduled nurse check-in within 24–48 hours, symptom diary, clear threshold for urgent evaluation) so it is not simply ‘hide the error.’ Alternatively, if you want current facts to stand, remove the ‘policy says permissible’ and make the correct ethical action clearer—otherwise the case reads as a guideline-fixed ‘disclose’ scenario.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove emotionally loaded or leading language that frames disclosure as harmful. For example, replace “cause panic, unnecessary urgent care visits, and loss of trust” with more neutral phrasing such as “may increase parental anxiety and prompt unplanned evaluation.” Also avoid quoting “doesn’t want surprises,” or present it as a documented preference: “has previously expressed desire for timely communication about changes in care.”

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify the clinical/ethical stakes and avoid internal ambiguity. Specify which vaccines were duplicated (e.g., DTaP, Hib, PCV13, HepA) or state “routine 18‑month vaccines per schedule” once, then refer to “duplicate dose.” Remove redundant reassurance (“otherwise well,” “unlikely to cause lasting injury”) or keep one concise sentence. Clarify the forcing constraint: e.g., “mother is reachable today; after-hours coverage is limited; next scheduled visit is in 6 months.”

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Shorten choices to ~10–15 neutral words and avoid embedded details. For example: Choice 1: “Disclose the duplicate vaccine dose to the mother today.” Choice 2: “Defer disclosure until the next visit unless symptoms prompt contact.” Keep monitoring instructions and documentation details in the vignette, not the choices.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Make Choice 2 ethically/clinically defensible rather than reading as concealment: (1) add a plausible reason immediate full disclosure today could cause serious foreseeable harm (e.g., parent has history of panic attacks leading to ER visits and abruptly stopping all vaccines for siblings; immediate disclosure without support likely to trigger this), and (2) add a concrete, ethically important benefit to delaying (e.g., allows you to first consult immunization registry/risk management, arrange same-day nursing follow-up plan, and disclose in a supported setting). Also add an explicit moral cost to Choice 1 beyond “panic” (e.g., increased likelihood the family disengages from care or refuses future vaccines, with foreseeable health consequences).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close off obvious middle options by specifying constraints and tightening the binary. For example: state you have only two feasible contact routes today—(A) leave a detailed voicemail/portal message now vs (B) wait for an in-person disclosure at a scheduled visit—because the mother cannot be reached live and has asked not to discuss medical issues with anyone else. Alternatively, explicitly rule out ‘disclose today with social work/nurse present’ by stating those supports are unavailable until next week. Remove ‘unless symptoms arise,’ which creates a third pathway (watch-and-wait + disclose if symptoms).

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, standard professional norms generally favor prompt disclosure of medical errors, making Choice 2 appear to violate an established expectation. To restore gray-zone ambiguity, modify the scenario so guidelines/standards do not clearly dictate timing/content today—e.g., the duplicate dosing is not yet confirmed (registry/chart discrepancy), and disclosing an unverified error could itself be misleading; or the only way to disclose today is via non-secure voicemail/with a third party, creating a confidentiality conflict. Add a brief line that institutional risk management has advised that in these specific circumstances (unconfirmed error or privacy barrier), either immediate disclosure via imperfect channel or delayed in-person disclosure is permissible.

data.vignette: An 18-month-old girl receives routine intramuscular immunizations per schedule after you confirm no contraindications. Later the same day, you notice a charting discrepancy suggesting she may have received the same set of vaccines at a visit the prior week. If a duplicate dose occurred, most children do well, but fever, marked local swelling, or other reactions can occur and could affect how future vaccines are timed. The mother has a documented history of severe health anxiety that has led to repeated unplanned ED visits and stopping vaccines after alarming news. She has also asked that medical issues not be left on voicemail, and she is not answering calls today; the only way to reach her before close is a brief portal message that may be read without support. If you wait, you can confirm the immunization registry and lot numbers and arrange a nurse call tomorrow morning with clear triage guidance. Risk management advises that either immediate portal disclosure or a documented, time-limited delay for verification and planned disclosure is legally permissible. You must decide before end of day.
data.choice_1: Send a portal message today disclosing the possible duplicate vaccine dose.
data.choice_2: Delay disclosure until a planned call tomorrow after verifying the immunization record.

choice_2.choice: Delay disclosure until a planned call tomorrow after verifying the immunization record.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause that if a duplicate dose occurred, the child could develop symptoms overnight where earlier parental monitoring/antipyretics or urgent evaluation could prevent complications, explicitly making same-day disclosure potentially beneficial to the child.

Add one clause specifying that immediate disclosure could trigger the mother to stop all future vaccines or bring the child to the ED, and one clause specifying that delaying disclosure could delay evaluation if the child develops fever/local swelling overnight.

Add one clause making a justice-relevant resource/fairness issue explicit (e.g., “the clinic is managing a same-day vaccine shortage/limited nurse triage capacity, and unnecessary after-hours ED visits strain shared resources”).

data.vignette: An 18-month-old girl receives routine intramuscular immunizations per schedule after you confirm no contraindications. Later the same day, you notice a charting discrepancy suggesting she may have received the same set of vaccines at a visit the prior week. If a duplicate dose occurred, most children do well, but fever or marked local swelling can develop overnight. Earlier parental monitoring, antipyretics, or urgent evaluation could reduce complications and could affect how future vaccines are timed. The mother has a documented history of severe health anxiety that has led to repeated unplanned ED visits and stopping vaccines after alarming news. She has also asked that medical issues not be left on voicemail, and she is not answering calls today; the only way to reach her before close is a brief portal message that may be read without support. The clinic has limited nurse triage capacity, and avoidable after-hours ED use strains shared resources. Risk management advises that either immediate portal disclosure or a documented, time-limited delay for verification and planned disclosure is legally permissible. You must decide before end of day.
